Posts.Content: On Sep 04, 2008 12:00 AM cacann wrote:   On 9/1/2008 kah49 wrote: I have had stage 2 breast cancer, (small tumor but it had spread to lymph nodes), also her2 positive. i have finished chemo and radiation and am now 5 months into the herceptin treatments. I also had double mastectomy. I would like to hear from someone who has been diagnosed as being her2 positive, and has had the herceptin treatments. I guess i would just like to know that there is hope at the end of this journey. My dr says that my cure rate is at about 70 to 80 percent, but I read that sometimes the herceptin does not always work. Even though my cure rate is pretty high, I still get nervous, after reading some of the info on breast cancer. Maybe I should just quit reading so much, huh? ha ha Thank you for any info k I have been diagnosed with breast cancer stage 2 in December 2007.  I am also her2 positive.  I had about a third of my left breast removed and had a second surgery to remove the rest of the lymph nodes  in that area and under my arm as they found a small tumor on one of the lymph nodes under my arm after the first surgery.  I have been treated very agressively since January 2008 with 7 chemo treatments ( sceduled for 8, but could not tolerate the last one) and 34 radiation treatments.  I was given herceptin in smaller amounts during my regular chemo treatments.  Now, I go every three weeks for a two hour drip of herceptin along with a Femora chemo tablet daily.  However, I was told this herceptin can only be used by individuals that have a certain type of cancer and they have to be her2 positive.  I understand the herceptin actually targets and kills any of these tumor cancer cells in your body.   I have regular blood tests that will tell if I have this type of cancer cells in my body.  You might ask your doctor about that.  If you need it, I will find out the name of the test.  So far, so good!  I hear unbelievable survival stories at the cancer center I go to, even with stage four cancer.  I do know trying to keep a positve attitude is healing, but sometimes it is a struggle to keep positive.  Ten years ago, you and I might not have survived with this diagnosis.  Great strides have been made concerning breast cancer, and I am greatful and thankful to God.  I know I am going through this for a reason.  Hopefully, a really good reason.  Good luck to you and I hope this helps. A   I found a lump in August, the following mammogram showed up calcifications aswell. Had a mastectomy 16th August. Fortunately not travelled to lymph nodes. Told I didn't need further treatment. Since then they had more results back and I am HER2positive. Now I''ve been told I need Herceptin and chemo. I don't understand why I need chemo now if they got all the cancer. I think they are just being cautious. You mention a blood test to see if there are any HER2+ cancer cells in the body - do you know any more about this? I would rather not have chemo unless I actually need to! The consultant says the chemo is of no benefit to me whatsoever, but they don't give Herceptin on its own. I need to decide whether to go ahead with chemo + herceptin. Any thoughts anyone?
Posts.Title: herceptin
